text: Applies common post-processing effects to the results of Pyro solves.

The Pyro Post-Process node provides common post-processing operations
for Pyro solvers.  It can adjust the visualization and material for
both viewport display and rendering.  And it can bake flame values into
the density map to ensure Mantra picks up purely emissive regions.

Controls if any updates to the smoke visualization or material will
    occur.  Turn this off to just process the geometry without affecting
    its appearance.

Control if a local shader is assigned to the geometry, ensuring
    the appearance in the renderer will match the viewport.
NOTE: This will override any materials defined at the object level.

The density of the smoke is multiplied by this value.  This allows the
    smoke to be made thicker or thinner without changing the actual values.

Controls the overall smoke color.  This will set the primitive color
    attribute for the smoke which will cause most shaders to tint
    appropriately.
When disabled, no light will be emitted by the fire.

The final brightness of the emissive part of the fire will be scaled
    by this amount.  This is applied after the flame range and flame
    intensity ramps.
The flame volume will be remapped to

from this range.  This
    allows the isolation of specific band of the evolution of the flame.

The flame volume, after fitting from the range, will be remapped with
    this map.  This controls how the flame intensity changes as the flame
    ages.  Often it is useful to have a sharp cut off to make for clean
    ends to flames.

Scales the flame volume by this and does a maximum of this with density.
    This is required for smokeless regions that otherwise may be skipped
    by the renderer.  To get a truly zero alpha channel, the smoke density
    can be set to 0.

How to convert temperature into fire color.  Physical Blackbody 
    uses the black body emission spectrum so provides an excellent
    physically correct starting point, and should be used for most
    normal fire.   But if rendering into different color spaces,
    or some more magical effect is desired, an explicit ramp can
    be provided.

The minimum and maximum temperature values to map to the left and
    right parts of the temperature ramp.  This is the raw volume values,
    so usually is in a 0 to 1 range.

A ramp mapping the temperature volume into an emissive color.  The
    color is multiplied with the flame intensity so the final brightness
    will depend on both this color’s brightness and the intensity.  Usually
    this ramp is used to drive the chroma primarily, but it can also be
    used to brighten or darken the flame with temperature.

Scales the temperature volume.  This is useful for adjusting the
    apparent temperature of the flame without changing the simulation.

When casting shadows the smoke’s density volume, after being scaled
    by the density scale, will be scaled again by the shadow density.
    This allows for volumes which cast heavier or lighter shadows.

This button will create a Pyro Shader material in /mat and a Material
    SOP to bind to it.  The settings of the new material will match the
    current settings of the post process, allowing for copying values
    into another pipeline or switching to more advanced material
    options.

Computes the minimum and maximum values of each volume and stores
    it as a primitive attribute of the same name.  If the volume is
    vector type and is converted to VDB, the maximum length is stored.
